Message.Title: 5-YR Chart Implies $22 short term
Message.Msg: The 50 bar has broken above the 200 bar which is when the fuddyduddies in the pension funds start buying. The volume action in YHOO has been encouraging, and looks like a new strong base is forming. YHOO's share buybacks in the $14s/$15s look great now. The next wave of buybacks should propel it higher. Hope Romney is not a party pooper and loses quietly. Could get a massive Obama rally on Wednesday, if the results are what the polling shows.

Topic.Title: REPUBLICANS, MITT ROMNEY, GW BUSH = BAD FOR AMERICA

Message.Msg: Get rid of O'vomit and the Democrap Congress!

Topic.Title: REPUBLICANS, MITT ROMNEY, GW BUSH = BAD FOR AMERICA

Message.Msg: You'd be more believable if you could articulate the ways that Obama is good for America. Obama did square up the war on terror to focus on terrorists and stopped the economic spiral with the lowest interest rates in 50+ years and the Fed Reserve getting into the business of buying out of the market almost all long term treasuries and then buying nearly all of the new issues. The people around his are mostly business bashers. He spends almost no time buttering up his opposition, of 104 games of golf only one was spent with a republican congressman. His record on keeping campaign promises is dismal: transparency, climate change, immigration, ignored his own bowles simpson commission, the health reform has huge costs and lots of red tape. I won't go on.

Topic.Title: Buffett and Yahoo

Message.Msg: Berkshire holds $13 billion of IBM, not a quite "merely" a position, more like a major stake. Also checked on Decker... former President of Yahoo, Susan, is still on the Berkshire board of directors. When you are seeking an elephant size deal the number of prey is quite limited. Plus Jerry Yang with his large position might favor a buyer like BRK, finding a nice home for "his children"?

Topic.Title: Buffett and Yahoo

Message.Msg: According to some of the books I read, Warren Buffett has an Yahoo account where he uses for online bridge games. Also, a few months ago, he mentioned on CNBC that Yahoo had a "trust" issue when the news were out for the firing of Yahoo's former CEO. My guess is he is a frequent Yahoo user and that he does realized Yahoo is a value stock. But given, the unpredictable nature of this business. I do not think he will buy

Message.Title: AOL up $8 bucks, YHOO up 9 cents!!?? Unreal! And this time last year Tim Armstrong was....
Message.Msg: ..putting out feelers to YHOO about buying them out or some type of merger. Now if Jerry Yang had any sense he could have done a deal w/ AOL, made Armstrong the CEO of YHOO (instead of the long charade of PIPE deals and ending up with Scott Thompson) and YHOO would have owned the AOL patents and their suit against FB would have worked. Also the merged AOL/YHOO content would have led to synergies and cost savings. But Yang never really had much sense since the AG deal (and even that should have been done better, so as to not allow YHOO to be so screwed w/ Alipay) and turning down $47 bil from MSFT (about $40 a share in today's shares). Time for YHOO to start moving up but so far it has not done much.
